data.summary: Optimized settings for the divison 2 provided by Santiago Santiago.
data.game_display_settings:
#### Video Settings 
- **Windowed Mode:** Fullscreen
- **Resolution:** 1280 x 800
- **Refresh Rate:** 60hz
- **Enable Reduced Latency:** No
- **Enable DX12 Renderer:** Disabled
data.game_graphics_settings:
#### Graphic Settings
- **Shadow Quality:** Medium
- **Spot Shadows:** Medium
- **Spot Shadow Resolution:** Medium
- **Contact Shadows:** Sun Low
- **Resolution Scale:** 75%
- **Sharpening:** 007
- **Particle Detail:** Medium
- **Volumetric Fog:** Low
- **Reflection Quality:** Medium
- **Local Reflection Quality:** Medium
- **Vegetation Quality :** Medium (Low if experience low fps in some areas is due to this)
- **Sub-Surface Scattering:** On
- **Anisotrophic Filtering:** 8x
- **Parallax Mapping:** Yes
- **Ambient Occlusion:** High
- **Depth of Field:** Off
- **Object Detail:** 20 (or below)
- **Extra Streaming Distance:** 00
- **Neutral Lighting:** Off
- **Lens Flare:** On
- **Vignette Effect:** Off
- **Water Quality:** Medium
- **Chromatic Aberration:** Off
- **Projected Texture Resolution:** 512

data.additional_notes: May need a lock at 30 fps at endgame level, since this is a game that more than likely has more effects and things going on at the endgame. Otherwise if you overclocked your Steam Deck with 70hz, then you can lock to 35hz and allow for higher battery use through powertools. Overall great game and pretty well optimized. I got these settings from Santiago Santiago, link here: https://youtu.be/Zf-RyRVfwjg?si=z0zCMFVpSgDFMJAi

reports_summary: Looking at recent results, The Division 2 runs in the lowâ€“mid 30 FPS range on a Steam Deck LCD using community presets, giving a mixed feel with dips in busy scenes; locking to 30 FPS helps steady performance. Community tuning favours a 40 FPS cap alongside a reduced resolution scale (around 75%), which balances visual detail and responsiveness; overclocking can raise frame rates further but at the cost of considerably higher battery use.
